Let's start with the custard.

I'm going to take a crack

a savory creme anglaise.

First we're whisking
together three egg yolks

and one tablespoon of sugar
in a medium heatproof bowl.
Then, over on the stove top,

we've got three quarters
of a cup each heavy cream

and whole milk that we're
going to bring to a bare simmer
in a large saucier.

Once simmered, we're gonna
remove it from the heat
and very slowly stream into the egg yolks,
whisking constantly to temper them
so that they might not scramble.
Put everything back in the saucepan,

bring it back over to the
stovetop over medium-low heat,

and cook, whisking constantly,
taking off the heat
when necessary for two to three minutes
before straining and cooling.

Then, once relatively cool,
we're gonna add some stuff.
A tablespoon or two of chopped fresh dill,
one small dill pickle, finally minced,

and the freshly squeezed
juice of one entire lemon.

This, along with a generous
pinch of kosher salt

and a few twists of
freshly-ground black pepper

results in something
actually pretty delicious.

You can see when I grabbed

I really don't know

It's got all the flavors

First up, a dry dredge of

This is gonna soak up any excess moisture

on the exterior of the fish

After frying for four to five minutes,

so we don't end up with soggy fingies.

Rinse and repeat with the
